description:
The image illustrates a simplified representation of a hydrogen atom according to the Bohr model. At the center of the diagram is a small black dot representing the nucleus of the hydrogen atom. Surrounding this nucleus are concentric circular orbits labeled with quantum numbers: "n = 2" and "n = 3," indicating different energy levels of the electron within the atom. 

An arrow labeled "Light" is shown curving outward from the "n = 3" orbit toward the "n = 2" orbit, symbolizing the emission of light when an electron transitions from the higher energy level (n = 3) to the lower energy level (n = 2). This transition corresponds to the release of energy in the form of a photon of light.

The diagram does not explicitly depict the "n = 1" level, but it is implied by the context of the question that it exists at a lower energy level than both "n = 2" and "n = 3." The transition from "n = 3" to "n = 1" would involve a larger drop in energy compared to the transition from "n = 3" to "n = 2," resulting in the emission of a photon with higher energy.

In the context of electromagnetic radiation, higher energy photons correspond to higher frequencies and shorter wavelengths. The speed of light remains constant in a vacuum, so option C is irrelevant. The momentum of a photon is directly proportional to its frequency, making option D relevant.

Therefore, if the transition were from the n=3 to the n=1 level instead, the light emitted would have:

D. greater momentum (due to the higher frequency associated with the larger energy difference between n=3 and n=1 compared to n=3 and n=2).
